I played the PS2 version of Half-Life 1 a while ago, but I quit the game after a while after not really finding it fun. I bought the Valve Collection recently and playing this game again, its quite fun. There are quite a few differences but I want to state why this game feels so good to play.

The engine and the weapons play with each other really well. Just smacking head crabs with a crowbar feels fluid in some sort of way and running around shooting things is just plain fun.

I've not really been a big fan of N64 era graphics and the first steps into 3D but the game has some weird charm to it that I can look through. When characters talk though you can tell the game is dated.

The story is ehh.. alright. Its exciting and more action packed than most games but it's completely lacking compared to the other games in the series. In my opinion.

Overall, get it. Its still a fun game and there's so much replayability that you can see why its one of Valve's most prominent game series'. This title will probably be a 7/10, a good start for the series.

유명한 한국어 더빙으로만 게임을 알고 있다가
직접해보니까 왜 FPS 명작인지 알 수 있었습니다.

2021년에도 분명 재미있는 명작이지만
오래 플레이하면 구린 그래픽과 구린 사운드, 계속되는 전투에 피로도가 너무 높아지고, 피로도를 적절하게 해소해주는 구간이나 수집요소 같은 것이 존재하지 않아서 결국 머리를 비우고 계속해서 나오는 적들을 죽이고 나아가기만 하는 킬링머신이 되버리는 게임. 

게임내에 지도도 네비게이션도 없는데, 일직선의 진행 방식, 직관적인 맵과 오브젝트 배치로 길찾기의 어려움을 줄이려는 노력은 군데군데 보이지만 편리한 시스템에 익숙해진 현대인에게는 그래도 조금 어려운 수준이다.


그러나 킬링머신이 되는 것은 한번에 너무 장시간 플레이했을때고, 길찾기도 공략이 곧곧에 있으니 아주 문제되는 수준은 아니다. 거기에 저 단점들을 제외하면 장점만 남는데, 몇가지를 꼽아보자면.
무기종류는 다양하고 적들의 종류도 다양하고, fps인데도 퍼즐같이 생각하여 클리어해야하는 스테이지를 만들어 두었음에도 퍼즐 요소는 딱 재미를 느낄만큼만 만들고 남는 공간에 전투를 채워둠으로서 퍼즐의 재미와 전투의 재미를 동시에 잡아내는 뛰어난 스테이지 구성, 재미있는 더빙, 명분만 만들어둔 서사가 아닌 제대로 흥미로운 내용을 갖춰둔 서사. 곳곳에 숨겨둬서 발견할때마다 재밌는 G맨까지...

Let me tell you a story
When I was 6 or 7 years old, I had a cracked version of CS 1.6, and one day I decided to browse the files, and I found hl.exe, and so I decided to open it
I did only the half of the training course because I didn't know how to rocket jump, keep in mind I didn't know English at that time
So I decided to play the single-player, I didn't know what that lady was saying, or who was I, or what I was supposed to do, I was just enjoying the view
Fast forward to the test chamber after I was running around like a maniac, I spent 10 or 20 minutes jumping around not knowing I had to climb up the ladder
After I pressed the button, I spent another 5 minutes wandering around until I pushed the cart
When the reactor started exploding, I went from being happy to being so scared that when I saw the Vortigaunts, I almost peed myself, I turned off my PC and went running to the bathroom
Never played Half-Life 1 Single-player for the next 8 years, but at least I was enjoying the hell out of multi-player instead

Absolutely brilliant.
I felt the need to write this review almost immediately after completing Half-Life (which was a very enjoyable 2 days, which is about the same amount of time as has passed in the game itself, funnily enough), and I would like to say that in spite of being an over 20 year-old game, Half-Life holds up well and is worth playing, and I'm very pleasantly surprised  and impressed with it.

While the clearly dated graphics, interface as well as the somewhat bare feel of Half-Life's setting may be offputting and do show the age of the game, I believe it also gives it a distinct charm. I have a list of points on which I'd like to remark upon:

GAMEPLAY
Having already played several Source games, and having no experience with non-Source FPS games, I was excited to see how Half-Life really worked... which is rather good, actually (with some notable exceptions)! I very much like how your character moves noticeably faster than in the Source games, and it definitely makes the game more fast-paced. This, I believe, is similar to older games such as those from the Doom or Quake series, which came out somewhere around the same time (and the games are obviously related, and it's nice to get a feel for how games of that era played). Generally speaking, Half-Life is also very pleasant to control.

The shooting worked mostly well, although sometimes it's hard to tell whether or not you're hitting an enemy. The Hivehand weapon was especially confusing to use. I was also surprised to see the physics (such as the gibs from smashed boxes), which I wasn't even aware was possible back in 1998.

A significant problem was getting stuck on objects, and an even greater problem was the completely broken nature of pulling objects, done by pressing the USE key and moving backwards. This always sent the object careening away by what amounts to several metres to the left or right with teriffic speed, and I suspect that it's a bug.

SOUND
The sound design, apart from the mostly very poor quality, adds to the gritty yet incidentally humorous and exaggerated atmosphere along with the flawless soundtrack, a great portion of which you will recognise from Half-Life 2. During my very first time playing I found myself walking continuously back and forth on the metal grates of the training course, then stopping and absorbing it along with the look of the map, as it turned to total silence... strangely amazing feeling.

Hearing complete and utter silence only interrupted by footsteps I also found quite fascinating, for some reason. This atmosphere of outdatedness and simplicity, even desolation, is something I can appreciate. With regards to the soundtrack, I especially enjoyed hearing "Drums and Riffs" during the rocket scene (I'm of course being vague to avoid spoiling it completely, but hey, this game is literally decades old), which had a particularly defiant and bold feel to it, so to say.

One genuine complaint one could make is the lack of consistency with the general sound quality, as well as the overuse of "stingers", the socalled short, suspenseful pieces of music meant to highlight the dark nature of a certain scene, also featured in Half-Life 2 (I believe I heard the same stinger at least 3 times). I also noticed that the music keeps going after you die or load a save file, which was quite awkward.

SETTING
By far one of Half-Life's biggest strengths is its setting and atmosphere. With tons of intriguing and wildly different maps, Half-Life is full of variety. The Black Mesa Research Facility, with its incomprehensible size, gives off a feeling of openness, and not once did the world feel boxy, claustrophobic or awkward. It felt very natural, with virtually no invisible walls to speak of. I enjoy the setting being in a barren canyon-type environment, conveying the sense that you're somewhere important to be held secret. Getting to explore it further and journeying down the deadly cliffs was also fantastic. I think it's a great setting for a secret lab, and a game in general because of the lack of anything important aside from ourselves and the characters and action immediately before us.
It does hurt the setting that the quality of the skyboxes is so extremely low.

The main setting also contrasts very well with the chaotic and macabre Xen. Overall, I think the environments and the game itself is very memorable and unique in terms of design.
The setting in the final scene is also a great callback to the beginning, in several ways, and its bizarre nature adds up to a great ending.

STORY
I appreciate the kind of story that poses questions and unsolved mysteries, and especially stories that don't need a backstory or long-winded introductory cutscene, but instead throws you right into it. Again, the datedness and simplicity of Half-Life works in favour of the game here. It's a very subtle way of introducting the player to the world of the game, and it's a recurring theme with a lot of Valve's games, especially the first Portal game, where it's done masterfully. In Half-Life, you get to piece the story together yourself without any metanarrative interruptions. It makes you feel like you're really there, in a way. Simplicity is the key here. Half-Life shows and basically never tells, which is what makes the universe of the game so captivating.

Half-Life can tell a story with a lot of mystique using very little, and the best example of this is the G-Man and his supposed associates. I would say that his puppetmaster-esque role and the power dynamic it poses is maybe the most interesting thing about the Half-Life universe. It also makes us ask even more questions about who your character, Gordon Freeman, actually is, considering his interactions with the G-Man.

OVERALL
As someone who originally played Half-Life 2 about 8 years ago, I'm glad to have played Half-Life 1. I look forward to play the extra levels from Opposing Force and Blue Shift next, and I'm very happy to have gotten all of these on sale! Half-Life is very much worth experiencing in spite of its age and I completely understand why it has had such an impact. It's been a pleasure to experience such a big part of video game/software history and I strongly recommend it.

It was fun to replay this game; from the gameplay to the quirky story, it was a real pleasure to play it again after such a long time.    I did have a couple issues while playing through it though. The game crashed to desktop many times, as well as my character getting stuck into the environment.  I even had an issue where a boss encounter near the end of the game didn't work properly; i actually had to consult a walkthrough on how to bypass it because it was bugged.
